\begin{abstract}

\vskip 10pt
Let $R$ be a ring and $T$ be a good Wakamatsu-tilting module with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$. We prove that  $T$ induces an equivalence between stable categories of repetitive algebras $\hat{R}$ and $\hat{S}$.




\zskip\



\noindent MSC2010: \ \  Primary 16E35 18E30 Secondary 16E05 16G10

\noindent {\it Keywords}: \ \ Wakamatsu-tilting module; cotorsion pair; repetitive algebra; stable equivalence

\end{abstract}


\vskip 10pt













\section{\large Introduction}




\ \ \
Tilting theory plays an important role in the representation theory of artin algebras. The classical tilting modules were introduced in the early eighties by Brenner-Butler \cite{BB}, Bongartz \cite{Bgz} and Happel and Ringel \cite{HR}. Beginning with Miyashita \cite{My} and Happel \cite{HR}, the defining conditions for a classical tilting module were relaxed to tilting modules of arbitrary finite projective dimension, and further were relaxed to arbitrary rings and infinitely generated modules by many authors such as Colby and Fuller \cite{CF1}, Colpi
and Trlifaj \cite{CT}, Angeleri-H\"{u}gel and Coelho \cite{AhC}, Bazzoni \cite{Bz} etc..

One important result in tilting theory is the famous Brenner-Butler Theorem which shows that a tilting module induces some equivalences
between certain subcategories. In this sense, tilting theory may be viewed as a far-reaching way of generalization of
 Morita theory of equivalences between module categories. More interesting, when considering the derived category of an algebra, which contains module category of the algebra as a full subcategory,  Happel \cite{Hpb} and later   Cline, Parshall and Scott \cite{CPS} proved that a tilting module of finite projective dimension induces an equivalence between the bounded derived category of the ordinary algebra and the derived category of the endomorphism algebra of the tilting module. This leads to the study of Morita theory for derived categories, which were completely solved by Rickard \cite{Ric} through the notion of tilting complexes and by Keller \cite{Kel} through dg-categories.


A further generalization of tilting modules to tilting modules of possibly infinite projective
dimension was given by Wakamatsu \cite{Wk1}. Following \cite{GRS},  such tilting modules of possibly infinite projective
dimension are called Wakamatsu-tilting modules. It is known that Wakamatsu-tilting modules  also induce some equivalences between certain subcategories of module categories \cite{Wk2}. But Wakamatsu-tilting modules don't  induce derived equivalences in general.



However, we will show in this paper that Wakamatsu-tilting modules make more sense when we consider a more general category than the derived category of an algebra, namely, the stable module category of the repetitive algebra  of an algebras. To be compared, let us call the later category the repetitive category of the algebra. The repetitive category is a triangulated category. Moreover, by Happel's result \cite{Hpb}, for an artin algebra $R$, there is a fully faithful triangle embedding of the bounded derived category of $R$ into the repetitive category of $R$. Moreover, this embedding is an equivalence if and only if the global dimension of $R$ is finite.

We say that two algebras are repetitive equivalent if there is an equivalence between their repetitive categories.
It should be noted that repetitive equivalences are more general than derived equivalences. In fact, by results in \cite{As, Chqh, Ric} etc., if two algebras are derived  equivalent, then their repeptitive algebras are derived equivalent, and hence stably
equivalent. Thus derived equivalences always induce repetitive equivalences.





The following is our main theorem.

\vskip 10pt

\noindent{\bf Main Theorem}\ \  {\it Let $R$ be an artin algebra. If $T$ is a good Wakamatsu-tilting $R$-module with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$, i.e., bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between a complete hereditary cotorsion piar $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and a complete hereditary cotorsion piar $({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$, then $R$ and $S$ are repetitive equivalent. The equivalence restricts to the equivalence between ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.}

\vskip 10pt

We refer to subsection \ref{gwt} for more details on  good Wakamatsu-tilting modules. Note that that examples of good Wakamatsu-tilting modules contain tilting modules of finite projective dimension and cotilting modules of finite injective dimension.

Though a good Wakamatsu-tilting module induces a repetitive equivalence, unfortunately we can't say anything about whether or not the equivalence is a triangle equivalence now. However, if a repetitive equivalence is a triangle equivalence, we have the following result.

\vskip 10pt
\noindent{\bf Proposition} {\it Let $R$ and $S$ are artin algebras. Assume that there is a triangle equivalence between their repetitive categories and that this equivalence restricts to an equivalence between a covariantly finite coresolving subcategory ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and a contravariantly finite resolving subcategory ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$. Let $T$ be the preimage in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ of $S$. Then $T$ is a good Wakamatsu-tilting $R$-module with $S\simeq{{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$.
}
\vskip 10pt


The paper is organized as follows. After the introduction, we provide basic knowledge on Wakamatsu-tilting modules and repetitive categories in Section 2. Then in Section 3 we introduce good Wakamatsu-tilting modules through cotorsion pair counter equivalences. Some properties and characterizations of good Wakamatsu-tilting modules are presented. Section 4  is devoted to the proof of the main theorem and the proposition in the introduction. Though the proof of the theorem is a little  complicated, the main idea is inspired by constructions in \cite[Lemma 4.1 in Chapter 3]{Hpb} and \cite[Section 1]{Wk2}. Finally, we provide some examples in the last section. In particular, it is shown that every Wakamatsu-tilting module over an algebra of finite representation type is a good Wakamatsu-tilting module and hence induces a repetitive equivalence.




\vskip 10pt
\noindent {\bf Conventions} Throughout this paper, we always work over artin algebras and right modules unless we claim otherewise. For an algebra $R$, we denote by ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ the category of all finitely generated $R$-modules, and by ${{\mathrm{{proj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ (resp., ${{\mathrm{{inj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$) the category of finitele generated projective (resp., injective) $R$-modules. We denote the usual duality over an artin algebra $R$ by $D$.

For two functors ${{\mathrm{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}:{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\to{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and ${{\mathrm{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}:{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\to {{\mathcal{{C}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, we use ${{\mathrm{{GF}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ to denote their composition. While we use $f\circ g$, or simply just $fg$, to denote the composition of two homomorphisms $f:A\to B$ and $g:B\to C$.

Let ${{\mathrm{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}:{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\to{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ be  a functor, we use ${{\mathrm{{KerF}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ to denote the subcategory of $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ such that ${{\mathrm{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(A)=0$. Moreover, if ${{\mathrm{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_i: {{\mathrm{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\to {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, $i\in I$, is a class of functors, we denote ${{\mathrm{{KerF}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{I}=\bigcap_{i\in I}{{\mathrm{{KerF}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. For instance, ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{\ge 1}(T,-)$ is the subcategory of all $M\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ such that ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^i(T,M)=0$ for all $i\ge 1$.

We write the elements of direct sums as row vectors.












\bskip\





\vskip 30pt

\section{{\large  Wakamatsu-tilting modules and repetitive categories}}

















{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{Wts}

{\bf Wakamatsu-tilting modules}



\zskip\

Recall that an $R$-module $T$ is {\it Wakamatsu-tilting} [\ref{Wk1}] provided that

\sskip\

(1) ${{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_ST\simeq R$, where $S:={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and,

(2) ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^i(T,T)=0={{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^i(T,T)=0$ for all $i>0$.


\sskip\

\noindent These two conditions are also equivalent to the following two conditions  [\ref{Wk1}].


\sskip\


(1) ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^i(T,T)=0$ for all $i>0$ and,

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
(2) There is an exact sequence $0\to R\to T_0\to T_1\to\cdots$, where $T_i\in {{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ for all $i$, which stays exact after applying the functor
${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(-,T)$.

\sskip\



Note that if $T$ is Wakamatsu-tilting and $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$, then $_S T$ is a Wakamatsu-tilting left $S$-module. In this case, we say that $T$ is a Wakamatsu-tilting
$S$-$R$-bimodule. It is easy to see that $DT$ is a Wakamatsu-tilting $R$-$S$-bimodule in the mean time.

\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{AC}

{\it Auslander class and co-Auslander class}

\zskip\

Let $T$ be a Wakamatsu-tilting module with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$. There are the following  two interesting classes associated with Wakamatsu-tilting modules.

The {\it Auslander class} in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ with respect to the Wakamatsu-tilting  module $T_R$, denoted by ${{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{T}$, is defined as follows [\ref{AR}].

\vskip 5pt\hskip 40pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 100pt
${{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T:=\{M\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R |$ there is an infinite exact sequence $0\to M\stackrel{f_0}{\longrightarrow} T_0\stackrel{f_1}{\longrightarrow} T_1\stackrel{f_2}{\longrightarrow} \cdots$ such that
${{\mathrm{{Im}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}f_i\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{\ge 1}(-,T)$ for each $i\ge 0 \}$.
\vskip 5pt

Obviously, it hold that ${{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T\subseteq {{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{\ge 1}(-,T)$. Moreover, the two classes coincide with each other provided that $T$ is a cotilting $R$-module.


Dually, the {\it co-Auslander class} in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ with respect to the Wakamatsu-tilting $R$-module $T$, denoted by ${_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$, is defined as follows.

\vskip 5pt\hskip 40pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 100pt
${_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}:=\{M\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R |$ there is an infinite exact sequence $ \cdots \stackrel{f_2}{\longrightarrow} T_1\stackrel{f_1}{\longrightarrow} T_0\stackrel{f_0}{\longrightarrow} M \to 0$ such that
${{\mathrm{{Im}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}f_i\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{\ge 1}(T,-)$ for each $i\ge 0 \}$.
\vskip 5pt

Similarly, we have that $_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq {{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{\ge 1}(T,-)$ and they coincide with each other provided that $T$ is a tilting $R$-module.



\zskip\ 
The following result collects some properties about Auslander class and co-Auslander class for a Wakamatsu-tilting module \cite{AR, MR, Wk2, Wk3}.

\zskip\

\noindent {\bf Proposition} 
{\it 
Let $T$ be a Waksmatsu-tilting $R$-module with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$.

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
$(1)$ The Auslander class ${{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$ is a resolving subcategory, i.e., it contains all projective $R$-modules and is closed under extensions, kernels of epimorphisms and direct summands.

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
$(2)$ The co-Auslander class $_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is  a coresolving subcategory, i.e., it contains all injective $R$-modules and is closed under extensions, cokernels of monomorphisms and direct summands.

$(3)$ ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,-)={{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{\ge 1}({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,-)\subseteq {_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$.

$(4)$ ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{1}(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})={{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{\ge 1}(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})\subseteq {{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$.

\hangafter 1\hangindent 39pt
$(5)$ The functors ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$ and $-\otimes_ST$ induce an equivalence between the co-Auslander class  $_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and the Auslander class
${{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$. The  equivalence restricts to an  equivalence between the class  ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{\ge 1}({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,-)$ and the class
${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^{\ge 1}(-,{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$.

}

\vskip 5pt
\Pf. (1) and (2) follows from \cite[Section 5]{AR}, see also \cite{MR}.

(3) and (4) follows from \cite[Lemma 1.4 and Proposition 1.6]{Wk3}.

(5) follows from  \cite[Proposition 2.14]{Wk2}.

\hfill $\Box$


\vskip 10pt
We remark that in case $T=R$, the class ${{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T={{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R$ is just the class of all Gorenstein projective $R$-modules. Dually, in case $T=DR$, the class ${_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}={_{DR}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$ is just the class of all Gorenstein injective modules. We refer to \cite{EJb} for more on Gorenstein projective and Gorenstein injective modules.

\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{cxt}

The following is a characterization of Auslander class and co-Auslander class, by \cite[Section 2]{Wk2} .

\vskip 10pt
\noindent {\bf Lemma} {\it Let $T$ be a Wakamatsu-tilting  $R$-module with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$. Assume $X\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ }

\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt
\noindent{\it $(1)$ $X\in{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$ if and only if $X\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{>0}(T,-)$, ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X)\in{{\mathrm{{KerTor}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^S_{>0}(-,T)$ and ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X)\otimes_ST\simeq X$ canonically.}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt
\noindent{\it $(2)$ $X\in{{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T}$ if and only if $X\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{>0}(-,T)$, ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(X, T)\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^{>0}(-,T)$ and ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(X,T),T)\simeq A$ canonically.}

\sskip\

\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{isom}
{\it Useful isomorphisms}


\vskip 10pt
Let $T$ be a Wakamatsu-tilting  $S$-$R$-bimodule. Then we have the following isomorphisms of bimodules.

\sskip\

 \centerline{$_SDS_S\simeq {_ST\otimes_R DT_S}$ and $_RDR_R\simeq {_RDT\otimes_S T_R}$.}


\sskip\

Given an adjoint pair $({{\mathrm{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathrm{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ of functors, we denote by ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ the natural adjoint isomorphism

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}:\ {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}({{\mathrm{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(-),-)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(-,{{\mathrm{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(-))$.}
\vskip 5pt

\noindent Moreover, for a homomorphism  $f: {{\mathrm{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(X)\to Y$, we denote by ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(f): X\to {{\mathrm{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(Y)$ the image of $f$ under the isomorphism  ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.


In particular, associated with a  $S$-$R$-bimodule $T$, we have the following adjoint isomorphism

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^T:\ {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(-\otimes_ST,-)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(-,{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-))$.}
\vskip 5pt

\noindent We denote by $\eta^T$ and $\epsilon^T$ the unit and counit of this adjoint pair respectively, i.e.,

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$\eta^T_X={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^T(1_{X\otimes_ST}): X\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X\otimes_ST)$ and}

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$\epsilon^T_Y=({{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^T)^{-1}(1_{{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Y)}): {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Y)\otimes_ST\to Y$ }

\vskip 5pt
\noindent for $X\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$ and $Y\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ respectively.

By the naturality of the isomorphism ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, for all homomorphisms $f:X_1\to X_2$, $g: {{\mathrm{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(X_2)\to Y_1$ and $h:Y_1
\to Y_2$, it holds that ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}({{\mathrm{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(f)\circ g\circ h)=f\circ {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(g)\circ {{\mathrm{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(h)$.

















































\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{rp}
{\bf Reprtitive algebras and Repetitive categories}

\vskip 10pt



{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{rpa}





 We recall some basic facts on repetitive algebras mainly from \cite{Hpb}.

Let $R$ be an artin algebra. The repetitive algebra $\widehat{R}$ of $R$ was first introduced in \cite{HW}), which is defined to be the direct sum $\widehat{R}=\bigoplus_{n\in\mathbb{Z}}R\oplus\bigoplus_{n\in\mathbb{Z}}DR$ with the multiplication given by

\centerline{$(a_n,\varphi_n)(b_n,\psi_n)_n=(a_nb_n,a_{n+1}\psi_n+\varphi_nb_n)_n$.}

\noindent The repetitive algebra $\widehat{R}$ can be interpreted as the following infinite matrix algebra (without the identity)

\vskip 10pt
{\footnotesize\centerline{$\left(\begin{array}{ccccc}\ddots&&&&\\
\ddots & R & & & \\
& DR &R & &\\
&&DR&R&\\
&&&\ddots&\ddots
\end{array}\right)$.}
}

\vskip 10pt




{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{rpm}



Denote by ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\widehat{R}$ the category of finitely generated $\widehat{R}$-modules. Then ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\widehat{R}$ is equivalent to the following two equivalent categories.

\vskip 5pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
(1) ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{\otimes}(R):=\{X=\{X_i,\delta^{\otimes}_i(X)\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}\mid X_i\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R $ such that almost all $X_i$ are 0 and that $ \delta^{\otimes}_i(X):X_i\otimes_RDR\to X_{i-1}$ satisfying $(\delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}(X)\otimes_RDR)\circ\delta^{\otimes}_i(X)=0$, for each $i\}$.

\vskip 5pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
(2) ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R):=\{X=\{X_i,\delta^{{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}_i(X)\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}\mid X_i\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R $ such that almost all $X_i$ are 0 and that $\delta^{{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}_i(X):X_i\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DR,X_{i-1})$ satisfying $\delta^{{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}_{i+1}(X)\circ  {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DR,\delta^{{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}_i(X))=0$, for each $i\}$.

\vskip 5pt

We will freely use these equivalences. In particular, we often view $X\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\widehat{R}$ as the following form with almost terms $X_i=0$

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$ \cdots\stackrel{\delta_{i+1}}{\rightsquigarrow}X_i \stackrel{\delta_{i}}{\rightsquigarrow}X_{i-1}\stackrel{\delta_{i-1}}{\rightsquigarrow}\cdots$.}

\noindent and we call it a (bounded chain) repe-complex with the repe-difference $\delta$. We denote by ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ the category of all such repe-complexes. Thus, ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)={{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\widehat{R}$. Note that there is an obvious automorphism $[1]:{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)\to{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ defined by $(X[1])_i=X_{i-1}$ for each $i$.


We say that a repe-complex $X=\{X_i,\delta_i\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ is trivial  if each $\delta_i=0$. The full subcategory of all trivial repe-complexes is denoted by ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$. Note that there is a natural forgetting functor from ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ to ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ by forgetting the repe-difference. 

Let ${{\mathcal{{C}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ be a class of $R$-modules, we denote by ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}({{\mathcal{{C}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ the class of repe-complexes with terms in ${{\mathcal{{C}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. The notation ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathcal{{C}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is defined similarly.


\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{rpc}




As shown in \cite{Hpb}, $\widehat{R}$ is a selfinjective algebra and the category ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)(={{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\widehat{R})$ is a Frobenius category, where the projective (and also injective) objects are of the form

\vskip 5pt

\centerline{$ \cdots\stackrel{\delta_{i+1}}{\rightsquigarrow}P_i\oplus I_i \stackrel{\delta_{i}}{\rightsquigarrow}P_{i-1}\oplus I_{i-1}\stackrel{\delta_{i-1}}{\rightsquigarrow}\cdots$,}

\vskip 5pt
\noindent where $P_i\in{{\mathrm{{proj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$, $I_i\in{{\mathrm{{inj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and $\delta_i={  \begin{pmatrix} {{0}} & {{\delta'_i}} \\ {{0}} & {{0}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ such that $\delta'_i: P_i\otimes_RDR\to I_{i-1}$ is an isomorphism (considered in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{\otimes}(R)$), or equivalently, $\delta'_i: P_i\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DR, I_{i-1})$ is an isomorphism (considered in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$).
Thus its stable category $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ is a triangulated category. To compare with the derived category of an algebra, we will call it the {\it repetitive category} of ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ (or simply, of $R$).

It was shown in \cite{Hpb} that there is a fully faithful triangle embedding from the derived category ${{\mathcal{{D}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^b({{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R)$ to the repetitive category $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$. Moreover, there is a triangle equivalence between ${{\mathcal{{D}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^b({{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R)$ and $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ if and only if $R$ has finite global dimension.


\vskip 5pt
For basic knowledge on triangulated categories,  derived
categories and the tilting theory, we refer to \cite{Hpb}.







\zskip\
\zskip\
\section{{\large Cotorsion pairs and good Wakamatusu-tilting modules}}

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{cotp}
{\bf Cotorsion pair counter equivalences}


\vskip 10pt

A pair of subcategories $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ is called a cotorsion pair, if ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}={{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ and  ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}={{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},-)$. A cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is called hereditary provided that ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is resolving, or equivalently, ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is coresolving. Moreover, a cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is called complete provided that, for each $X\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$, there exist exact sequences $0\to X\to A\to B\to 0$ and $0\to A'\to B'\to X\to 0$ for some $A,A'\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and $B,B'\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. We refer to the book \cite{GT} for the general results on cotorsion pairs.

Let $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ be a cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and  $({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$  be a cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$. Similarly to torsion theory counter equivalences studied in \cite{CF, CDT},  we say that there is a {\it cotorsion pair counter equivalence} between $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ and  $({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ provided that there are an equivalence ${{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}: {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\  {^{\longrightarrow}_{\longleftarrow}} \ {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0} :{{\mathrm{{T}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and  an equivalence ${{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{\prime}: {{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0} \ {^{\longrightarrow}_{\longleftarrow}}\ {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0} :{{\mathrm{{T}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{\prime}$. Moreover, we say that two bimodules $_SV_R$ and $_RV_S'$ represent the cotorsion pair counter equivalence if ${{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(V,-)$, ${{\mathrm{{T}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}=-\otimes_SV$ and  ${{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}'={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(V',-)$, ${{\mathrm{{T}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}=-\otimes_RV'$.

There are close relations between Wakamatsu-tilting modules and cotorsion pairs, as shown in the following proposition.

\vskip 10pt

\noindent {\bf Proposition} {\it Let $T$ be a Waksmatsu-tilting $R$-module with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$.} 

\hangafter 1\hangindent 39pt
{\it $(1)$ Both pairs $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ and $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,-))$ are hereditary cotorsion pairs.}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 39pt
{\it $(2)$ The bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between the cotorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and  the cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT},{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT},-))$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$.}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 39pt
{\it $(3)$ The  bimodules $_RDT_S$ and $_ST_R$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between the cotorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1(-,{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$  in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$ and the cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{T},{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{T},-))$  in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$.
}







\vskip 5pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
\Pf. (1) follows from \cite[Proposition 3.1]{MR} and Propsition \ref{AC}. \\
(2) follows from Propositon \ref{AC} (5).\\
 (3) is obtained from (2) by replacing $_ST_R$ with $_RDT_S$.


\hfill $\Box$



\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{gwt}
{\bf Good Wakamatsu-tilting modules}


\vskip 10pt


{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{dgwt}





In general case, the two cotorsion pairs in Proposition \ref{cotp} (1) are not complete. For instance, consider the case $T=R$. Then ${{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R$ is the class of all Gorensten projective modules. It is well known that this class is not a precovering class in general, see for instance \cite{Yo}. Thus, the cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R,{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R,-))$ cannot be complete. Dually, in case $T=DR$, the cotorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_{DR}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_{DR}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ is not complete in general.

However, the other cotorsion pair of  the  two cotorsion pairs in Proposition \ref{cotp} (1) for the above examples is complete respectively. This leads to the following general definition.






\vskip 10pt

\noindent {\bf Definition} {\it A Wakamatsu-tilting bimodule $_ST_R$ is said to be {\bf good} if the bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between a compete hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and a compete hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$. Furthermore, an $R$-module $T$ is said to be  a good Wakamatsu-tilting module if $_ST_R$ is a good Wakamatsu-tilting bimodule with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$}.

\vskip 10pt
For example, $R$ and $DR$ are good Wakamatsu-tilting modules.


\vskip 10pt


{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{pgwt}
By the definition, we have the following property about good Wakamatsu-tilting bimodules.


\vskip 10pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 39pt
\noindent {\bf Proposition} {\it Let $_ST_R$ be a good Waksmatsu-tilting bimodule. Assume that  $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is  a compete hereditary cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$  and  $({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is a compete hereditary cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$ such that the bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between them. Then


\hangafter 1\hangindent 39pt
$(1)$\ \ There is an equivalence \\
 \centerline{${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-):\hskip 20pt {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\ \ \  {^{\longrightarrow}_{\longleftarrow}}\ \ \ {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\hskip 20pt  :-\otimes_ST$\ \ \ }
  and  an equivalence \\
  \centerline{${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,-):\hskip 20pt {{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\ \ \  {^{\longrightarrow}_{\longleftarrow}}\ \ \ {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\hskip 20pt  :-\otimes_RDT$.}


\hangafter 1\hangindent 39pt
$(2)$\ \  $_RDT_S$ is also a good Waksmatsu-tilting bimodule.



$(3)$\ \  ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$, ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\in {_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$ and ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}$, ${{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq {_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$.



$(4)$\ \  ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT= {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SDT= {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.
}

\vskip 10pt

\Pf. (1)  follows from the definition of good Wakamatsu-tilting bimodules.

(2) Replacing the Waksmatsu-tilting bimodule $_ST_R$ with the Wakamatsu-tilting bimodule $_RDT_S$ and noting that $DDT=T$, one can obtain (2) directly.


(3)\ \  Firstly, we show that   ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT\subseteq{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SDT\subseteq {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.

 Note that all the involved subcategories in (1) are  closed under finite direct sums and direct summands.  Since ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is resolving, we have that $S\in {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. By the first equivalence in (1), we obtain that $T=S\otimes_ST\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. It follows that ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT\subseteq {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Dually, since ${{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is coresolving, we have that $DS\in{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. It follows from the second equivalence in (1) that $T={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(S,T))={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,DS)\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Hence, ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT\subseteq {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ too. Thus, we obtain that  ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT\subseteq{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.
Dually, one also has ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SDT\subseteq {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.

Clearly, ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}={{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})={{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^{\ge 1}(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^{\ge 1}(-,T)$ follows from  ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT\subseteq{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and the fact that $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is a complete and hereditary cotorsion pair. Take any $B\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, then $B\otimes_RDT\in{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Take an exact sequence $0\to B\otimes_RDT\to I\to Y\to 0$ with $I\in{{\mathrm{{inj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S={{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SDS$. Since ${{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is coresolving, we have that $I,Y\in{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ too. Applying the functor ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,-)$, we obtain an induced exact sequence $0\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,B\otimes_RDT)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,Y)\to 0$, since ${{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}={{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},-)\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1(DT,-)$ by the above argument. Note that $B\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,B\otimes_RDT)$, ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I)\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,Y)\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, so one can easily see that $B\in{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$. Thus ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$. By the equivalence in Proposition \ref{cotp} (3), we also obtain that ${{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq {_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$.

Now consider the good Wakamatsu-tilting module $_RDT_S$ and apply the above result, we can obtain that ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\in{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}$ and that ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\in {_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$.

 

(4)\ \ If $X\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, then $X\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Following from the proof of (3), we obtain that there is an exact sequence $0\to X\to T_X\to X'\to 0$ with $T_X\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and $X'\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Since $X\in {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ too, we have that ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(X',X)=0$. It follows that the exact sequence splits. Hence $X\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$. Together with the first claim in the proof of (3), we obtain that ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT= {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Dually, we also have that ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SDT= {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.

 \hfill $\Box$
















\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{homlem}




Recall that a subcategory ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ is covariantly finite (or, a preenveloping calss) if for any $X\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$, there is an object $A_X\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and a homomorphism $u_{_X}: X\to A_X$ such that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(u_{_X},A)$ is surjective for any object $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, see for instance \cite{AR}. Dually,  a subcategory ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ is contravariantly finite (or, a precovering calss)  if for any $X\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$, there is an object $B_X\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and a homomorphism $v_X: B_X\to X$ such that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,v_X)$ is surjective for any object $B\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.

Let ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ be a subcategory of ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$. An $R$-module $T$ is said to be Ext-projective if $T\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$. Moreover, it is said to be an Ext-projective generator if, for any $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, there exists an exact sequence $0\to A'\to T_A\to A\to 0$ with $T_A\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and $A'\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.  Dually, an $R$-module $T$ is said to be an Ext-injective cogenerator if $T\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},-)$ and that,  for any $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, there exists an exact sequence $0\to A\to T_A\to A'\to 0$ with $T_A\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and $A'\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.



\vskip 10pt
\noindent{\bf Lemma} {\it Let ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ be a subcategory closed under extensions and direct summands.}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 35pt
{\it $(1)$ Assume that ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ has an Ext-projective generator $T$. If $0\to X\to Y\to Z\to 0$ is an exact sequence which stays exact after the functor ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$, where $Y,Z\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, then $X\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ too.}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 35pt
{\it $(2)$  Assume that ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ has an Ext-injective cogenerator $T$. If $0\to X\to Y\to Z\to 0$ is an exact sequence which stays exact after the functor ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(-,T)$, where $X,Y\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, then $Z\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ too.
}

\vskip 5pt
\noindent\Pf. (1) By the assumptions, we can construct the following commutative diagram, where $T_Z\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and $Z'\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.

 \hskip 120pt$\xymatrix@C=20pt@R=20pt{
               &             & 0\ar[d]        &       0\ar[d]          & \\
               &             & Z'\ar[d]\ar@{=}[r]&      Z'\ar[d]   & \\
          0\ar[r]& X\ar[r]^{(1,0)\ \ \ }\ar@{=}[d] &X\oplus T_Z\ar[r]^{\ \ \ (^0_1)}\ar[d]^{(^f_h)} &T_Z\ar[dl]^h\ar[r]\ar[d]^t&0\\
          0\ar[r]& X\ar[r]_{f}  &Y\ar[r]_{g}\ar[d]  &Z\ar[r]\ar[d]&0\\
               &             & 0         &       0         &} $


\vskip 5pt
Since ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is closed under extensions and direct summands, we have that $X\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ from the middle column.

(2) Dually.

\hfill $\Box$





\vskip 10pt




{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{res-cor}
\hangafter 1\hangindent 35pt
\noindent{\bf Lemma} {\it Let $T$ be a Wakamatsu-tilting $R$-module with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$. Assume that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-): {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\  {^{\longrightarrow}_{\longleftarrow}} \ {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0} : -\otimes_ST$ define an equivalence. Then the following are equivalent.}

{\it $(1)$ ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is coresolving and $T$ is an Ext-projective generator in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.}

{\it $(2)$ ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is resolving and $DT$ is an Ext-injective cogenerator in ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.}


\vskip 5pt
\noindent \Pf. (1) $\Rightarrow$ (2) The condition that  $T$ is an Ext-projective generator in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ says that $T\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(T,-)$ and that every $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ admits an exact sequence $0\to A'\to T_A\to A\to 0$ with $T_A\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and $A'\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. This implies that ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^{\ge 1}(T,-)$,  since ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is coresolving. In particular, ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq {_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$.

Note that, for any $X\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, there is an exact sequence $0\to X\to I\to X'\to 0$ with $I'\in{{\mathrm{{inj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R\subseteq{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and $X'\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Applying the functor ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$, we have an exact sequence $0\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,I)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X')\to 0$. Since ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,I)\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SDT$ and ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X),DT)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X),{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,DR))=0$,  we obtain that $DT$ is an Ext-injective cogenerator in ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})={{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.

It is clear that ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is closed under direct summands. Assume now there is an exact sequence $(\flat):\  0\to X\to Y\stackrel{g}{\longrightarrow} Z\to 0$ with $Z\in{{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, then $Z\in{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerTor}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^S_1(-,T)$. Applying the functor $-\otimes_ST$, we obtain an induce exact sequence $(\flat\otimes_ST):\  0\to X\otimes_ST\to Y\otimes_ST\stackrel{g\otimes_ST}{\longrightarrow} Z\otimes_ST\to 0$. 

Assume first $X\in{{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ too, then $X\otimes_ST\in {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. It follows that $Y\otimes_ST\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ too, since ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is closed under extensions. Note now there is an exact sequence  $0\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X\otimes_ST)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Y\otimes_ST)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Z\otimes_ST)\to 0$, so we have that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Y\otimes_ST)\simeq Y$ since ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X\otimes_ST)\simeq X$ and ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Z\otimes_ST)\simeq Z$. Thus $Y\in{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})={{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. This shows that ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is closed under extensions.

Assume now $Y\in{{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, then ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,g\otimes_ST)\simeq g$. In particular, we have that  ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X\otimes_ST)\simeq X$ and the homomorphism ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,g\otimes_ST)$ is surjective. It follows that the exact sequence $(\flat\otimes_ST)$ stays exact after the functor ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$. By Lemma \ref{homlem}, we obtain that $X\otimes_ST\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Hence $X\in {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})={{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. This shows that ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is closed under  kernels of epimorphisms.

(2) Dually.


\hfill $\Box$

 
\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{cequ}
\noindent{\bf Proposition} {\it Let $_ST_R$ be a Wakamatsu-tilting module. Assume that $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is a hereditary cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and that $T$ is an Ext-projective generator in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, then $({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)$ is a hereditary cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$. In particular, the bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ and  $({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)$ in the case.
}

\vskip 5pt
\noindent\Pf. Since $T$ is an Ext-projective generator in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, we see that $T\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})\bigcap {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}={{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and that, for any $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, there is an exact sequence $0\to A'\to T_A\to A\to 0$ with $T_A\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and $A'\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. In particular, for any $X\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, there is an exact sequence $0\to X'\to T_X\to X\to 0$ with $T_X\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and $X'\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, which is clearly split. Hence, $X\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$. It follows that ${{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT={{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Moreover, by  an argument similar to the one used in the proof of \cite[Proposition 2.13(b)]{MR}, we have that $T$ is also an Ext-injective cogenerator in ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Note that these  imply that ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq {_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$ and that  ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq {{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T}$.

By Lemma \ref{res-cor}, we see that  ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is resolving and that ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT$ is coresolving. It is also clear that the bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a counter equivalence between two pairs $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ and  $({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)$, by assumptions.  So, it just remains to show that $({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)$ is a cotorsion pair.

We divide the remained proof into three steps.

\vskip 5pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
\noindent {\bf Step 1}  ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^i_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),B\otimes_RDT)=0$, for any $A\in {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and any $B\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and for any $i\ge 0$.

\vskip 5pt
 Note that there is an isomorphism $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(S,B\otimes_SDT)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,S\otimes_ST)$ and that it induces an isomorphism $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(S_i,B\otimes_SDT)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,S_i\otimes_ST)$, for any $S_i\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SS$.

Now take $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, since $T$ is an Ext-projective generator, there is a long exact sequence

\hskip 90pt{$\cdots\to T_n\to\cdots \to T_1\to T_0\to A\to 0$}\hfill $(\dag)$

\noindent with each $T_i\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and each image in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Since  $B\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,A)$, we have an induced exact sequence ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,\dag)$:

\hskip 20pt{\footnotesize$\cdots\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,T_n)\to\cdots \to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,T_1)\to  {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,T_0)\to  {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,A)\to 0$.}

 On the other hand, by applying the functor $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-),B\otimes_RDT)$, we have a complex $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,\dag),B\otimes_RDT)$:

\vskip 10pt

{\footnotesize\hskip 20pt{$\cdots\to D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,T_n),B\otimes_RDT)\to\cdots \to D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,T_1),B\otimes_RDT)$}

 \hskip 40pt{$\ \ \ \ \to  D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,T_0),B\otimes_RDT)\to  D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),B\otimes_RDT)\to 0$.}}


Since ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,\dag)$ is exact, one sees that the functor  $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-),B\otimes_RDT)$ is right exact. By the above isomorphism, we obtain the following isomorphisms of complexes

\hskip 40pt{ {\footnotesize$D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,\dag),B\otimes_RDT)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,\dag)\otimes_ST)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,\dag)$.}}

\noindent But the later is exact, so we obtain that

\vskip 10pt
\hskip 40pt{\footnotesize{${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^i_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),B\otimes_RDT)\simeq {{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^i({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,\dag),B\otimes_RDT))$

\hskip 40pt $\simeq D{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^i(D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,\dag),B\otimes_RDT))\simeq D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,\dag)=0$.}}



Thus, step 1 is established. In particular, we obtain that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})
\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S(-,{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)$ and that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})
\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S(-,{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)$, due to the arbitrarity of $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and $B\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$.

\vskip 5pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
\noindent {\bf Step 2}\ \  ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S(-,{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)\subseteq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$.

\vskip 5pt

Take any $Y\in {{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S(-,{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)$ and a projective resolution of $Y$:

\vskip 5pt
\hskip 90pt $\cdots\stackrel{f_{n+1}}{\longrightarrow} S_n\stackrel{f_n}{\longrightarrow}\cdots\stackrel{f_1}{\longrightarrow} S_1\stackrel{f_1}{\longrightarrow} S_0\stackrel{f_0}{\longrightarrow} Y\to 0$. \hfill ($\sharp$)

Note that $DT=R\otimes_RDT\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT$ and that  ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT $ is coresolving, so we obtain that

\hskip 10pt{\footnotesize $Y\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S(-,{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)={{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^{>0}(-,{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^{>0}(-,DT)={{\mathrm{{KerTor}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^S_{>0}(-,T)$.}

\noindent Then we have an induced exact sequence:

\hskip 40pt $\cdots\to S_n\otimes_ST\to\cdots\to S_1\otimes_ST\to S_0\otimes_ST\to Y\otimes_ST\to 0$.  \hfill $(\sharp\otimes_ST)$

For any $B\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, applying the left exact functor ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,-)$, we obtain a complex $ {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,\sharp\otimes_ST)$:

\vskip 10pt
\hskip 40pt {\footnotesize $\cdots\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,S_n\otimes_ST)\to\cdots\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,S_1\otimes_ST)$

\hskip 90pt $\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,S_0\otimes_ST)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,Y\otimes_ST)\to 0$.}

Applying the right exact functor $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(-,B\otimes_SDT)$ to the sequence ($\sharp$), we obtain a complex $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(\sharp,B\otimes_SDT)$:

\vskip 10pt
\hskip 40pt {\footnotesize $\cdots\to D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(S_n,B\otimes_SDT)\to\cdots\to D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(S_1,B\otimes_SDT)$

\hskip 90pt $\to D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(S_0,B\otimes_SDT)\to D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(Y,B\otimes_SDT)\to 0$.}

By the isomorphism in Step 1 again, we have isomorphisms of complexes

\hskip 90pt $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(\sharp,B\otimes_SDT)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,\sharp\otimes_ST)$.

\noindent It follows that, for any $i\ge 2$,

\vskip 10pt
\hskip 70pt {\footnotesize ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(B,Y_{i}\otimes_ST)\simeq{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{i-1}({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,\sharp\otimes_ST))$

\hskip 100pt $\simeq{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{i-1}(D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(\sharp,B\otimes_SDT))=D{{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{i-1}_R(Y,B\otimes_ST)=0$,}

\noindent where $Y_i={{\mathrm{{Im}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}f_i$, since $B\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,T)$ and ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(B,-)$ is left right exact. This shows that $Y_i\otimes_ST\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},-)={{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, for all $i\ge 2$. As $S\otimes_ST\simeq T\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is coresolving, we obtain that $Y\otimes_ST\in {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ too. Then we have an induced exact sequence ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,\sharp\otimes_ST)$:


\vskip 10pt
\hskip 40pt {\footnotesize $\cdots\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,S_n\otimes_ST)\to\cdots\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,S_1\otimes_ST)$

\hskip 90pt $\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,S_0\otimes_ST)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Y\otimes_ST)\to 0$.}

\noindent It follows that $Y\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Y\otimes_ST)\in{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$, since $S_i\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,S_i\otimes_ST)$ for each $i$. This shows that ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S(-,{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)\subseteq{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$. Together with Step 1, we obtain that ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S(-,{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$.

\vskip 5pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
\noindent {\bf Step 3}\ \  ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),-)\subseteq {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT$.

\vskip 5pt

Note that there is an isomorphism \\
\centerline{${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),DS)\simeq D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,DS),A)$,}\\
for any $A\in{{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and that it induces an isomorphism

\hskip 90pt ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),I_i)\simeq D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I_i),A)$, 

\noindent for any $I_i\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}DS$.

Now take any $X\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),-)$ and 
consider an injective resolution of $X$:

\vskip 5pt
\hskip 90pt $0\to X\stackrel{g_0}{\longrightarrow} I_0\stackrel{g_1}{\longrightarrow} I_1\stackrel{g_1}{\longrightarrow}\cdots\stackrel{g_{n-1}}{\longrightarrow} I_n \stackrel{g_n}{\longrightarrow} \cdots$. \hfill $(\natural)$

\noindent Since $DT\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,DR)\in{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ and ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is resolving, we obtain that


\hskip 20pt {\footnotesize $X\in {{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),-)={{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^{>0}({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),-)\subseteq {{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^{>0}(DT,-)$}.


Thus, for any $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, applying the functor ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),-)$, we have an induce exact complex ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),\natural)$:


\vskip 5pt
\hskip 80pt {\footnotesize $0\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),X){\longrightarrow} {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),I_0) $}

\hskip 110pt {\footnotesize ${\longrightarrow}{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),I_1){\longrightarrow}\cdots {\longrightarrow} {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),I_n) {\longrightarrow} \cdots$}.

On the other hand, we also have the following induced complex  $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,\natural),A)$, by applying the functor $D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,-),A)$: 


\vskip 5pt
\hskip 80pt {\footnotesize $0\to D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,X),A){\longrightarrow} D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I_0),A) $}

\hskip 110pt {\footnotesize ${\longrightarrow}D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I_1),A){\longrightarrow}\cdots {\longrightarrow} D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I_n),A) {\longrightarrow} \cdots$}.



By the above mentioned isomorphism $(\ast)$ and the fact that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,\natural)$ is exact, we have that, for any $i\ge 1$,

\vskip 5pt
\hskip 70pt {\footnotesize ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,X_{i+2}),A)\simeq {{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{i}({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,\natural),A))$}

\hskip 100pt {\footnotesize   $\simeq D{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{i}(D{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,\natural),A))\simeq D{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{i}({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A),\natural))=0$,}

\noindent where $X_i={{\mathrm{{Im}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}g_i$, since $A\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,T)$ and ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(-,A)$ is left exact. It follows that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,X_{i+2})\in{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})={{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ for any $i\ge 1$. Since ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is resolving, we also obtain each ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,X_{i})\in {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ for for each $0\le i\le 2$, where $X_0:=X$. Then we have an induced exact sequence ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,\natural)\otimes_RDT$,  since ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,T)={{\mathrm{{KerTor}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^R_1(-,DT)$:

\hskip 40pt {\footnotesize $0\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,X)\otimes_SDT\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I_0)\otimes_SDT$}

\hskip 80pt {\footnotesize $\to{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I_1)\otimes_SDT\to\cdots\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I_n)\otimes_SDT\to\cdots$.}

\noindent It follows that $X\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,X)\otimes_SDT\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_SDT$, since $I_i\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,I_i)\otimes_SDT$ for each $i$. This shows  that ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),-)\subseteq{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT$. Together with Step 1, we obtain that ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_S({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),-)={{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT$.

\vskip 5pt
Altogether, we obtain that $({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\otimes_RDT)$ is a hereditary cotorsion pair.
 

\hfill $\Box$

\vskip 10pt




{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{c-gwt}
\noindent{\bf Corollary} {\it Let $T$ be a Wakamatsu-tilting $R$-module with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$. Assume that the functor ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$ gives an equivalence between a covariantly finite coresolving subcategory ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and  a contravariantly finite resolving subcategory ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$. If $T$ is an Ext-projective generator in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, then $T$ is a good Wakamatsu-tilting module.}

\vskip 5pt
\noindent\Pf. Since ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is  a contravariantly finite resolving subcategory in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$, there is a cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},-))$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$, by \cite[Proposition 1.10]{AR}. Dually,  there is a cotorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}),{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$, since ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is  a covariantly finite coresolving subcategory ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$. Note that both  cotrosion pairs are complete and hereditary. Since  $T$ is an Ext-projective generator in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, by Proposition \ref{cequ}, the bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between the above two cotorsion pairs. Hence $T$ is a good Wakamatsu-tilting module by the definition.





\hfill $\Box$





\vskip 30pt

\section{\large The proof of the main results}


\ \ \ \ \

The whole section will be devoted to the proof of the two results mentioned in the introduction.

Let $R$ be an artin algebra and $T$ be a good Wakamatsu-tilting module with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$. Then $_ST_R$ be a good Wakamatsu-tilting bimodule.  Assume that  $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is  a compete hereditary cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$  and  $({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is a compete hereditary cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$ such that the bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between these two  cotorsion pairs.


The sketch of our proof on the main theorem is as follows.

Firstly we construct a functor  ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T: {{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)\to{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$ and a functor $-\hat{\otimes} DT :{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)\to{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$. Then we give a natural homomorphism

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$l^X_Y:{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}(X,Y)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)}(X\hat{\otimes}DT,{{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(Y))$}
\vskip 5pt

\noindent which is functional in both variables. After this, associated with an object $X\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$, we use the condition that  $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is  a compete cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ to obtain an object $A_X\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ and  establish a homomorphism $u_{_X}\in {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}(X,A_X)$. We then show that the assignment that setting $X\longmapsto {{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_X}))$ induces our desired functor ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T: \underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)\to\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$. We use the dual method to construct another desired functor ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}:  \underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)\to \underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$. Then we prove that there are natural  isomorphisms  ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T\simeq 1_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}$ and ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T{{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}\simeq 1_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}$.

\vskip 10pt




{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{rpc}\label{S}
{\bf From ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ to ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$: the functor ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$}


{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{0-l}\label{FcL}
{\it The functor ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T: {{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)\to{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$
}

\vskip 10pt

Let $X=\{X_i\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$. We define ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$ as follows.

\sskip\






$(l1)$ The underlying module ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)_i={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X_{i-1})\oplus X_i\otimes_R DT$ and,

\hangafter 1 \hangindent 41pt
$(l2)$ The structure map  $\delta^{\otimes}_i({{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)): {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)_i\to {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)_{i-1}$ is given by $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & \delta_{L_i}\\ 0 & 0\end{pmatrix}$,  where $\delta_{L_i}$ is the composition:




{\footnotesize \hskip 5pt\centerline{${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X_{i-1})\otimes_S DS \stackrel{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X_{i-1})\otimes_S T\otimes_R {{\mathrm{{D}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}T\stackrel{\epsilon_{X_{i-1}}^T\otimes_R
{{\mathrm{{D}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}T}{\longrightarrow} X_{i-1}\otimes_R DT.$}}

\vskip 5pt


From the functor  property of ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$ and $-\otimes_R DT$, one can easily see that ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$ is a functor from ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ to ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$. 

\vskip 10pt


\noindent{\bf Remark}  (1) If $X\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT)$, i.e.,  $X=\{X_i\}$ with each  $X_i\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$, then ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X_{i-1})\in {{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SS$ and $\delta_{L_i}$ defined above is an isomorphism for each
$i$. It follows that ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$ is a projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$ in the case.



(2) In particular, in case $T=R$, we obtain the functor ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R: {{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)\to{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ which specially send objects in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RR)$ to  a projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$.



\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{r-r}
{\it The functor $-\hat{\otimes} DT :{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)\to{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$ 
 }
\vskip 10pt


Let $Y=\{Y_i,\delta^{\otimes}_i(Y)\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$. We  define $Y\hat{\otimes} DT\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$ by setting 

\sskip\

$(t1)$ the underlying module is $(Y\hat{\otimes} DT)_i=Y_i\otimes_RDT$ and,

$(t2)$ the structure map $\delta^{\otimes}_i(Y\hat{\otimes} DT)$ is given by the composition

\vskip 5pt
\hskip 25pt {\footnotesize $Y_i\otimes_RDT\otimes_SDS \stackrel{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} Y_i\otimes_RDT\otimes_ST\otimes_RDT  \stackrel{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}
Y_i\otimes_RDR\otimes_RDT\stackrel{\delta^{\otimes}_i(Y)\otimes_RDT}{\longrightarrow} Y_{i-1}\otimes_RDT$}.


\sskip\

From the functor property of $-\otimes_R DT$, one can see that $-\hat{\otimes} DT$ is a functor from ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ to ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$.


\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{lpro}\label{lhom}
{\it The homomorphism  $l^X_Y:{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}(X,Y)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)}(X\hat{\otimes}DT,{{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(Y))$ 
}



\vskip 10pt
Recall that we have a forgotting functor from ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ to ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$.
