 For any $X\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ and $Y\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$, there is a canonical homomorphism

\vskip 5pt
 \centerline{$l^X_Y: {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}(X,Y)\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)}(X\hat{\otimes}DT,{{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(Y))$ }
\vskip 5pt

 \noindent which is functional in both variables, defined by



\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$l^X_Y: u=\{u_i\}$ \hskip 10pt $\longmapsto$ \hskip 10pt $f=\{f_i\}$ with $f_i={ \begin{pmatrix} {{-\theta_{l_i},}} & {{{u_i\otimes_RDT}}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$,}
\vskip 5pt



\noindent where $\theta_{l_i}$ is given by the composition

 
\sskip\


\hskip 10pt {\footnotesize $X_i\otimes_RDT\stackrel{\eta^T_{X_i}}{\longrightarrow} {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X_i\otimes_R DT\otimes_ST)\stackrel{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,X_i\otimes_RDR)$

\sskip\
 \hskip 150pt $\stackrel{{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,\delta_{X_i})}{\longrightarrow} {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,
X_{i-1})\stackrel{{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,u_{i-1})}{\longrightarrow}{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Y_{i-1})$.}


\vskip 10pt

\noindent{\bf Remark} Using the fact ${_RDR_R}\simeq {_R(DT\otimes_ST)_R}$ and the adjoint isomorphism \\
\centerline{${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{T}: {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(X_i\otimes_RDR,Y_{i-1})\simeq{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(X_i\otimes_RDT,{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,Y_{i-1}))$,}\\ one can easily check that $\theta_{l_i}$ is just the image of the natural homomorphism $\delta^{\otimes}_i(X) \circ u_{i-1}$ under $\Gamma^T$, i.e., $\theta_{l_i}={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{T}(\delta^{\otimes}_i(X) \circ u_{i-1})$.





\zskip\


It is easy to see that, for any commutative diagram in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$

\vskip 5pt

  \centerline{  $\xymatrix{X\ar[r]^{u}\ar[d]^{x} & Y\ar@<-1ex>[d]^{y}\ \\
                X'\ar[r]^{u'}         & Y',
        }$ }


\vskip 5pt
\noindent there is an induced commutative diagram in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$



\vskip 5pt

 \centerline{ $\xymatrix{X\hat{\otimes}DT\ar[r]^{l(u)}\ar[d]^{x\hat{\otimes}DT} & {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(Y)\ar@<-1ex>[d]^{y}\ \\
              X'\hat{\otimes}DT\ar[r]^{l(u')}                          & {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(Y').
        }$}


\vskip 5pt


\bskip\










\zskip\





{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{resolution}

{\it A monomorphism $u_{_X}: X\to A_X$ with $A_X\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$, for $X\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$}.






\zskip\







Let $X=\{X_i\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$. Since $({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is a complete cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$, there are exact sequences $0\to X_i\stackrel{u_{_{X_i}}}{\longrightarrow} A_{X_i}\to B_{X_i}\to 0$ with $A_{X_i}\in {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and $B_{X_i}\in {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, for each $i$. This gives an exact sequence $0\to X\stackrel{u_{_X}}{\longrightarrow} A_X\stackrel{\pi_{u_{_X}}}{\longrightarrow} B_X\to 0$ in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ with $A_X=\{A_{X_i}\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ and $B_X=\{B_{X_i}\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$.

Now let $Y=\{Y_i\}\in {{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ and  $h=\{h_i\}\in{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)}(X,Y)$. Then we have an exact sequence $0\to Y\stackrel{u_{_Y}}{\longrightarrow} A_Y\stackrel{\pi_{u_{_Y}}}{\longrightarrow} B_Y\to 0$  in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ with $A_Y=\{A_{Y_i}\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ and $B_Y=\{B_{Y_i}\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$, as above.
Note that ${{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$,
it is easy to see that there is a homomorphism $h_{A}\in {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}(A_{X},A_{Y})$ and further $h_{B}\in {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}(B_{X},B_{Y})$,  such that the following diagram in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ is commutative with exact rows.


\vskip 5pt

  \centerline{  $\xymatrix{
 0\ar[r] & X\ar[r]^{u_{_X}}\ar[d]^{h} & A_X\ar[r]^{\pi_{{_X}}}\ar[d]^{h_A} & B_X\ar[r]\ar[d]^{h_B}&0 \\
 0\ar[r] & Y\ar[r]^{u_{_Y}}           & A_Y\ar[r]^{\pi_{{_Y}}}             & B_X\ar[r] & 0 \\
        }$ }


\bskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{coker}

{\it The cokernel ${{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_X}))$
}

\zskip\

Applying the functor $-\otimes_RDT$ to the exact sequences $0\to X_i\stackrel{u_{_{X_i}}}{\longrightarrow} A_{X_i}\to B_{X_i}\to 0$ in the above, we obtain an induced exact sequences

\vskip 5pt 
  \centerline{  $\xymatrix{
 0\ar[r] & X_i\otimes_RDT \ar@{->}[rr]^{u_{_{X_i}}\otimes_RDT} & & A_{X_i}\otimes_RDT\ar[r] & B_{X_i}\otimes_RDT\ar[r] & 0,}$
 }

\vskip 5pt

 \noindent
  since $B_{X_i}\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,T)={{\mathrm{{KerTor}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^R_1(-,DT)$ for each $i$. It follows that, by applying the homomorphism $l$ in \ref{lpro} to the homomorphism $u_{_X}$ in \ref{resolution}, there is an induced exact sequence


\centerline{$\xymatrix{
0\ar[r] & X\hat{\otimes}DT\ar@{->}[rr]^{l(u_{_X})}  & & {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(A_X)\ar@{->}[rr]^{\pi_{_{l_X}}} & & {{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l_{_X})\ar[r]  & 0.} $ }


\vskip 10pt

\noindent {\bf Remark} From the definition of ${{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_X}))$, one see that, for each $i$, ${{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_X}))_i$ is given by the pushout



  \centerline{  $\xymatrix{
             {X_i}\otimes_RDT\ar[r]^{\theta_{l_i}\  \  }\ar[d]_{u_{_{X_i}}\otimes_RDT} & {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A_{X_{i-1}})\ar[d] \\
                A_{X_i}\otimes_RDT\ar[r]          & {{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_X}))_i.
        }$ }



\vskip 10pt



Moreover, for  $Y\in {{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ and  $h\in{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)}(X,Y)$, by applying the homomorphism $l$ to the left square in the commutation diagram in \ref{resolution}, we obtain the following commutative diagram in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$, for some $h_{{{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$.

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$\xymatrix{
0\ar[r] & X\hat{\otimes}DT\ar@{->}[rr]^{l(u_{_X})}\ar[d]_{h\hat{\otimes}DT} & & {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(A_X)\ar@{->}[rr]^{\pi_{_{l_X}}}\ar[d]_{{{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(h_A)} & & {{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_X}))\ar[r]\ar[d]_{h_{{{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}} & 0 \\
0\ar[r] & Y\hat{\otimes}DT\ar@{->}[rr]^{l(u_{_Y})} & & {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(A_Y)\ar@{->}[rr]^{\pi_{_{l_Y}}}  & & {{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_Y}))\ar[r] & 0 \\
}$}



\bskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{functor}\label{Sfct1}

{\it The assignment ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T: {{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)\to \underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$ by setting $X\longmapsto {{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_X}))$ is a functor.
}


\zskip\

By \ref{coker}, it is sufficient to prove that ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(h):=h_{{{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}=0$ in $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$ provided $h=0$. We divide the proof into two steps.

{\it Step 1:} Consider each piece in the commutative diagram in \ref{resolution}. If $h=\{h_i\}=0$, then $h_i=0$ for each $i$. Thus, we have that $u_{_{X_i}}h_{A_i}=0$ and consequently, $h_{A_i}=\pi_{{_{X_i}}}g_i$ for some $g_i: B_{X_i}\to A_{Y_i}$. Since $B_{X_i}\in {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$ for each $i$, there are  exact sequences $0\to B_{X_i}\stackrel{b_i}{\longrightarrow}  T_{B_{X_i}}\to B_i'\to 0$ with $T_{B_{X_i}}\in {{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and $B_i'\in {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\subseteq{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$. It follows that there exists $t_i\in {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T_{B_{X_i}}, A_{Y_i})$ such that $g_i=b_it_i$. Altogether we obtain the following commutative diagram

\centerline{$\xymatrix{
A_{X_i}\ar[r]^{\pi_{{_{X_i}}}}\ar[d]_{h_{A_i}} &B_{X_i}\ar[d]^{b_i}\ar[dl]^{g_i} \\
A_{Y_i}  & T_{B_{X_i}}\ar[l]^{t_i}.
}$}

\vskip 10pt

\noindent This induces the following commutative diagram in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$, where  $T_{B_X}=\{T_{B_{X_i}}\}$.

\vskip 10pt
\centerline{$\xymatrix{
A_X\ar[r]^{\pi_{{_X}}}\ar[d]_{h_A} &B_X\ar[d]^b\ar[dl]^g \\
A_Y  & T_{B_X}\ar[l]^{t}.
}$}

\vskip 10pt


Set $k:= \pi_{{_X}}b$. Then ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(h_A)={{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(kt)={{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(k){{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(t)$.

\vskip 10pt

{\it Step 2}: Consider the commutative diagram in \ref{coker}.
 Since $u_{_{X_i}}\pi_{{_{X_i}}}=0$, we see that $l(u_{_X}){{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(k)=0$ by the definitions. Hence there is some $\theta\in{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)}({{\mathrm{{Coker}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_X})),{{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(A_Y))$ such that ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(k)=\pi_{l_X}\theta$.
Consequently, we have that ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(h_A)={{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(k)L(t)=\pi_{l_X}\theta {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(t)$. Now we obtain that $\pi_{l_X}h_{{{\mathrm{{Coker}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}} ={{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(h_{A})\pi_{l_Y}=\pi_{l_X}\theta {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(t)\pi_{{l_Y}}$. Since $\pi_{l_X}$ is epic, we get that $h_{{{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}} ={{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(h_{A})\pi_{l_Y}=\theta {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(t)\pi_{l_Y}$. That is, we have the following commutative diagram.

\vskip 10pt
\centerline{$\xymatrix{
{{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}({l(u_{_X})})\ar[r]^{\ \ \theta}\ar[d]_{h_{{{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}} & {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(T_{B_{X}})\ar[d]^{{{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(t)}  \\
{{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}({l(u_{_Y})})  & L(A_Y)\ar[l]^{\ \ \ \pi_{l_Y}}
}$}


\vskip 10pt
\noindent Note that ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(T_{B_X})$ is a projective-injective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$, so $h_{{{\mathrm{{Cok}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}=0$ in $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$.






\bskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{Sfct2}

{\it The functor ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T: \underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)\to\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$
}

\zskip\

We will show that the functor ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$ factors through $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$.

 To see this, it is enough to show that ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$ is a projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$ whenever $X$ is a projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$.

 W.l.o.g., we assume that $X=\{X_i\}$ is an indecomposable projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$.  Thus, 
  $X$ has the form





\vskip 5pt

\setlength{\arraycolsep}{3pt}
{\footnotesize
 \centerline{$\begin{array}{ccccccccccc}\cdots & \rightsquigarrow &  0 & \rightsquigarrow &  {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DR,I) & \stackrel{1}{\rightsquigarrow} &  I & \rightsquigarrow  & 0 & \rightsquigarrow & \cdots\end{array}$}
}
\vskip 5pt

  \noindent where $I$ is on the ($k$-1)-th position, for some $k$.

 Note that $X_k={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DR,I)\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RR\subseteq {{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and $X_{k-1}=I\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DR)\subseteq   {{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, so we can choose $A_X$ as  the form


\vskip 5pt
{\footnotesize
 \centerline{$\begin{array}{ccccccccccc}\cdots & \rightsquigarrow &  0 & \rightsquigarrow &  T_k & {\rightsquigarrow} &  I & \rightsquigarrow  & 0 & \rightsquigarrow & \cdots\end{array}$}
}
 

  \noindent

\noindent where $A_{X_k}=T_k\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$. And we have that the homomorphism $u_{_X}:X\to A_X$ is of the form

\vskip 5pt

{\scriptsize
\noindent\centerline{$\begin{array}{ccccccccccccccc} X:& & \cdots & \rightsquigarrow &  0 & \rightsquigarrow & 0 & \rightsquigarrow &  {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DR,I) & {\rightsquigarrow} &  I & \rightsquigarrow  & 0 & \rightsquigarrow & \cdots \\ \\
\ \ \ \downarrow u_{_X}& & & & & &   & & \ \ \ \ \downarrow u_k && \ \ \ \downarrow 1&&&&\\ \\
A_X:& & \cdots & \rightsquigarrow &  0 & \rightsquigarrow & 0 & \rightsquigarrow &  T_k & {\rightsquigarrow} &  I & \rightsquigarrow  & 0 & \rightsquigarrow & \cdots
\end{array}$
}
}




Then, from the structure of $l(u_{_X})$, we can see that $l(u_{_X})$ is of the form

\vskip 10pt

{\scriptsize
\noindent\centerline{$\begin{array}{ccccccccccccccc} X\hat{\otimes}DT:& & \cdots & \rightsquigarrow &  0 & \rightsquigarrow & 0 & \rightsquigarrow &  {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DR,I)\otimes_RDT & {\rightsquigarrow} &  I\otimes_RDT & \rightsquigarrow  & 0 & \rightsquigarrow & \cdots \\ \\
\ \ \ \downarrow l(u_{_X})& & & & & & \downarrow & & \ \ \ \ \downarrow (-\theta_{l_k},u_k\otimes_DT) && \ \ \ \downarrow 1&&&&\\
 {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(A_X):& & \cdots & \rightsquigarrow &  0 & \rightsquigarrow &{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,T_k) & \stackrel{(0, \delta_{L_{k+1}})}{\rightsquigarrow} &  {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,I)\oplus T_k\otimes_RDT & {\rightsquigarrow} &  I\otimes_RDT & \rightsquigarrow  & 0 & \rightsquigarrow & \cdots
\end{array}$
}
}

\noindent where $\theta_{l_k}$ is defined as in  \ref{lpro} and $\delta_{L_{k+1}}$ is defined as in \ref{FcL} repectively. One checks that both homomorphisms $\theta_{l_k}$ and $\delta_{L_{k+1}}$ are in fact isomorphisms. So we obtain that  $S_T(X)={{\mathrm{{Coker}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(l(u_{_X}))$ is of the form


{\footnotesize
\noindent\centerline{$\begin{array}{ccccccccccccccc}
 & & \cdots & \rightsquigarrow &  0 & \rightsquigarrow &{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,T_k) & \stackrel{\delta'_{k+1}}{\rightsquigarrow} &  T_k\otimes_RDT & {\rightsquigarrow} &  0& \rightsquigarrow  & 0 & \rightsquigarrow & \cdots
\end{array}$
}}

\vskip 5pt

\noindent 
where $\delta'_{k+1}$ is the induced isomorphism: ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,T_k)\otimes_SDS\to T_k\otimes_RDT$. Since $T_k\otimes_RDT\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(T\otimes_RDT)={{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DS)$, we see that $T_k\otimes_RDT$ is an injective $S$-module and that ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$ is a projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$.



It follows that the functor ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$ factors through $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$. We still denote by ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$ the induced functor from $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ to $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$.








\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{func2}\label{Q}
{\bf From $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$ to $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$: The functor ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}$}

\zskip\

The functor ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$ is indeed defined in a way dual to the construction of ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$.





{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{0-w}\label{rFct}

}

Dually to \ref{FcL}, for any $X=\{X_i\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$, we define ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(X)\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ as follows.

\vskip 5pt
$(r1)$ the underlying module is ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(X)_i={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,X_i)\oplus X_{i+1}\otimes_S T$ and,

$(r2)$ the structure map $\delta^{{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}_i({{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT})$ is given by ${  \begin{pmatrix} {{0}} & {{\delta_{R_i}}} \\ {{0}} & {{0}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, where
 $\delta_{R_i}$ is the composition

  \hskip 40pt $ {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,X_{i})\stackrel{{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,\eta^T_{X_{i}})}{\longrightarrow} {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T, X_{i}\otimes_S T))$

 \hskip 190pt $\simeq
 {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DT\otimes_S T, X_{i}\otimes_S T)$

  \hskip 190pt $\simeq
 {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(DR, X_{i}\otimes_S T)$.


It is easy to see that ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}$ is a functor.



\vskip 10pt


\noindent{\bf Remark}  (1) If $X\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SDT)$, i.e.,  $X=\{X_i\}$ with each  $X_i\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SDT$, then ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,X_{i})\in {{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RR$ and $\delta_{R_i}$ defined above is an isomorphism for each
$i$. It follows that ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(X)$ is a projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ in the case.



(2) In particular, in case $T=S$, we obtain the functor ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DS}: {{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)\to{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$ which specially send objects in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_SDS)$ to  a projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$ .

$(h2)$ the structure map $\delta^{{{\mathrm{{H}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}_i({{\mathrm{{\hat{H}om}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT, Y))$ is given by the composition:

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{epi}

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{Qfct1}

By \ref{ker}, it is sufficient to prove that ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(h):=h_{{{\mathrm{{Ker}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}=0$ in $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ provided $h=0$. This is also divided into two steps.

{\it Step 1:} Consider each piece in the commutative diagram in \ref{epi}. If $h=\{h_i\}=0$, then $h_i=0$ for each $i$. Thus, we have that $h_{G_i}v_{Y_i}=0$ and consequently, $h_{G_i}=g_ik_{v_{Y_i}}$ for some $g_i: G_{X_i}\to K_{Y_i}$. \centerline{$\xymatrix{
G_{X}\ar[r]^{t}\ar[dr]^{g}\ar[d]_{h_{G}} &DT_{K_{Y}}\ar[d]^{b} \\
G_{Y}  & K_{Y}\ar[l]^{k_{v_{_{Y}}}}.
}$}

Set $\beta:=bk_{v_{Y}}$. Then ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(h_G)={{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(t\beta)={{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(t){{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(\beta)$.

\vskip 5pt
{\it Step 2}: Consider the commutative diagram in \ref{ker}.
 Since $k_{v_{Y_i}}v_{Y_i}=0$, we see that ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(\beta)r(v_Y)=0$ by the definitions. Hence there is some $\theta\in{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)}({{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(G_X),{{\mathrm{{Ker}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(r(v_Y)))$ such that ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(\beta)=\theta\lambda_{r_Y}$.

Since $\lambda_{r_Y}$ is monomorphic, we get that $h_{{{\mathrm{{Ker}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}} =\lambda_{r_X}{{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(t)\theta$. That is, we have the following commutative diagram.


\centerline{$\xymatrix{
{{\mathrm{{Ker}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}({r(v_X)})\ar[r]^{\lambda_{r_X}}\ar[d]_{h_{{{\mathrm{{Ker}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}} &{{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(G_{Y})\ar[d]^{{{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(t)}  \\

\bskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{Qfct2}

Take any $X=\{X_i,\delta^{\otimes}_i\}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$.

Denote that $P^+_{A_X}:=\{P_{A_{X_{i+1}}}\}$, then $P^+_{A_X}\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{{{\mathrm{{tr}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}({{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RR)$. Applying the functor  ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R$ in the remark in \ref{FcL}, we obtain that  ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})$ is a projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$. Hence, the object $X\oplus  {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})$ is isomorphic to $X$ in $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$.

We will prove that ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)\simeq X\oplus  {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})$ naturally. And then, ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T \simeq 1_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}$.

The general strategy is as follows. Firstly, we construct a natural homomorphism $\xi: X\oplus {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})\to {{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})$. Secondly, we show that $\xi\circ r(s^P)=0$, i.e.,  the composition of $\xi$ and the homomorphism $r(s^P): {{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})\to {{\mathrm{{\hat{H}om}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(DT, {{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X))$ in the exact sequence above is 0. Thus, we obtain a homomorphism $\phi: X\oplus {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})\to {{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$. Finally, we prove that $\phi$ is indeed a  natural isomorphism.

 Recall from \ref{QSX} that $s^P=\{s^P_i\}=\{{  \begin{pmatrix} {{s^1_i}} \\ {{(p_i\otimes_RDT)\circ s^2_i}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\}: {{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X}\to {{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$. By \ref{rhom}, we know that ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})=\{{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})_i)\oplus ({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})_{i+1}\otimes_ST\}$ and that $r(s^P)_i={  \begin{pmatrix} {{{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,s^P_i)}} \\ {{-\zeta_{r_i}}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, where $\zeta_{r_i}={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((s^P_{i+1}\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))$.
























For convenience, we set $r(s^P)_i={  \begin{pmatrix} {{r^1_i}} \\ {{r^2_i}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, where

\vskip 10pt
\hskip 50pt $r^1_i={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,s^P_i): {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})_i)\to {{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)_i$ and

\vskip 10pt
\hskip 50pt $r^2_i=-\zeta_{r_i}: ({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})_{i+1}\otimes_ST\to {{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)_i$.





\vskip 10pt
{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesubsub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}\ (\roman{Exesubsub})}}\hskip 10pt}\label{xi-rsp=0check}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
{\it Checking $\xi\circ r(s^P)=0$
}



\vskip 10pt

To check  $\xi\circ r(s^P)=0$, we need only to check that $\xi_i^ar^1_i+\xi_i^br^2_i=0$ for each $i$, since $\xi_i=(\xi_i^a,\xi_i^b)$ and $r(s^P)_i={  \begin{pmatrix} {{r^1_i}} \\ {{r^2_i}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Note that $r^1_i={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,s^P_i)$ and $r^2_i=-\zeta_{r_i}$, so it is enough to check that $\xi^a_i\circ {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,s^P_i)=\xi_i^b\circ \zeta_{r_i}$.


\vskip 10pt

Since {\footnotesize $\xi_i^a={  \begin{pmatrix} {{\xi^a_{11}}} & {{0}} \\ {{0}} & {{\xi^a_{22}}} \\  {{0}} & {{0}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$},
      {\footnotesize $\xi_i^b={  \begin{pmatrix} {{\xi^b_{11}}} & {{0}} \\ {{\xi^b_{21}}} & {{0}} \\  {{0}} & {{\xi^b_{32}}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$},
      $\zeta_{r_i}={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((s^P_{i+1}\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))$ and
       $s^P_i={  \begin{pmatrix} {{s^1_i}} \\ {{(p_i\otimes_RDT)\circ s^2_i}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, we just check the following.


 \vskip 10pt
 \vskip 10pt
\noindent $(1)$ $\xi^a_{11}\circ{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,s^1_i)=\xi^b_{11}\circ {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((s^1_{i+1}\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))$.

 \vskip 10pt
\hskip 20pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt 
By \ref{xi-a}, we have that

 \vskip 10pt
\hskip 40pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 45pt  $\xi^a_{11}\circ{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,s^1_i)={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(\theta_{l_i})\circ{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,s^1_i)={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(\theta_{l_i}\circ s^1_i)$,
 \vskip 10pt

\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt
where later equality uses the naturality of ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}$. On the other hand, by \ref{xi-b} and \ref{s-fx}, we obtain that

 \vskip 10pt
\hskip 40pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 45pt  $\xi^b_{11}\circ {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((s^1_{i+1}\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))$\\
  $ =(u_{_{X_i}}\circ (\epsilon^T_{A_{X_i}})^{-1})\circ  {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((\epsilon^T_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_R DT) \circ s^2_i)$\\
  $ ={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(((u_{_{X_i}}\circ (\epsilon^T_{A_{X_i}})^{-1})\otimes_RDT)\circ (\epsilon^T_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_R DT) \circ s^2_i)$\\
  $ ={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((u_{_{X_i}}\otimes_RDT)\circ  s^2_i)$.
 \vskip 10pt

\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt
But $(u_{_{X_i}}\otimes_RDT)\circ  s^2_i= \theta_{l_i}\circ s^1_i$ by the pushout diagram on ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)_i$ in \ref{QSX}. Hence, the equality (1) holds.



 \vskip 10pt
\noindent $(2)$ $\xi^a_{22}\circ{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,(p_i\otimes_RDT)\circ s^2_i)=\xi^b_{21}\circ {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((s^1_{i+1}\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))$.

\vskip 10pt
\hskip 20pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt 
By \ref{xi-a} and  the naturality of ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}$,

 \vskip 10pt
\hskip 40pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 45pt  $\xi^a_{22}\circ{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,(p_i\otimes_RDT)\circ s^2_i)$\\
$={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(1_{P_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_RDT})\circ{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,(p_i\otimes_RDT)\circ s^2_i)$\\
$={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(1_{P_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_RDT}\circ ((p_i\otimes_RDT)\circ s^2_i))$\\
$={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((p_i\otimes_RDT)\circ s^2_i)$.

\vskip 10pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt
On the other hand, by \ref{xi-b} and \ref{s-fx} and   the naturality of ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}$,

 \vskip 10pt
\hskip 40pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 45pt  $\xi^b_{21}\circ {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((s^1_{i+1}\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))$\\
$=(p_i\circ (\epsilon^T_{A_{X_i}})^{-1})\circ  {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((\epsilon^T_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_R DT) \circ s^2_i)$\\
  $ ={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(((p_i\circ (\epsilon^T_{A_{X_i}})^{-1})\otimes_RDT)\circ (\epsilon^T_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_R DT) \circ s^2_i)$\\
  $={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((p_i\otimes_RDT)\circ  s^2_i)$.

 \vskip 10pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt
Hence, the equality (2) holds.



 \vskip 10pt
\noindent $(3)$ $0=\xi^b_{32}\circ {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(((p_{i+1}\otimes_RDT)\circ s^2_{i+1})\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))$.

 \vskip 10pt
\hskip 20pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt
In fact, the equality holds by observing that

 \vskip 10pt
\hskip 40pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 45pt  ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(((p_{i+1}\otimes_RDT)\circ s^2_{i+1})\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))$\\
$={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}((p_{i+1}\otimes_RDT\otimes_SDS) \circ (s^2_{i+1}\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))$\\
$=0$,

 \vskip 10pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt
 since $(s^2_{i+1}\otimes_SDS)\circ \delta^{\otimes}_{i+1}({{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)))=0$ by \ref{s-fx}.

 \vskip 10pt
All together, we prove that $\xi\circ r(s^P)=0$ and therefore, $\xi$ factors through ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)={{\mathrm{{Ker}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(r(s^P))$ by a homomorphism  $\phi: X\oplus {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})\to {{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$ in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$, i.e., $\xi=\phi\circ \lambda$.




\vskip 10pt
{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{xi-iso}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
{\it The induced homomorphism $\phi: X\oplus {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})\to {{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$ is an isomorphism
}



\vskip 10pt

We now prove that the induced  homomorphism $\phi: X\oplus {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})\to {{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$ is an isomorphism. Clearly it is equivalent to show that $\phi_i: (X\oplus {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X}))_i\to {{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)_i$ is an isomorphism,  for each $i$.

We will show that  there is the following commutative diagram ($\ast$) with exact rows, for each $i$, where $\overline{X}_i\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is obtained in \ref{QSX}. Note that ${{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})_i={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A_{X_i})\otimes_S T\oplus P_{A_{X_{i+1}}}\otimes_R DT\otimes_S T\simeq A_{X_i}\oplus P_{A_{X_{i+1}}}\otimes_R DR$.

\vskip 10pt

\bskip\

Then, since $\overline{X}_i\in{{\mathcal{{B}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$  implies that $\eta_{\overline{X}_i}^{DT}$ is an isomorphism, we obtain that $\phi_i$ is also an isomorphism from the above commutative diagram.



\vskip 10pt
{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesubsub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}\ (\roman{Exesubsub})}}\hskip 10pt}\label{phi-up}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
{\it The upper row in the diagram $(\ast)$ is exact
}



\vskip 10pt

In fact, the pullback of $p_i: P_{A_{X_i}}\to A_{X_i}$ and $u_{_{X_i}}: X_i\to A_{X_i}$ in \ref{QSX} gives an exact sequence

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$0\to \overline{X}_i\stackrel{(-q_i,\overline{u}_{X_i})}{\longrightarrow} X_i\oplus P_{A_{X_i}}\stackrel{{\tiny _{{  \begin{pmatrix} {{u_{_{X_i}}}} \\ {{p_i}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}}}{\longrightarrow} A_{X_i}\to 0$,}
\vskip 5pt


\noindent since $p_i$ is surjective. The direct sum of the above exact sequence and the trivial exact sequence $0\to 0\to P_{A_{X_{i+1}}}\stackrel{1}{\longrightarrow}P_{A_{X_{i+1}}}\to 0$ gives us the exact sequence in the upper row in the diagram $(\ast)$.




\vskip 10pt
{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesubsub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}\ (\roman{Exesubsub})}}\hskip 10pt}\label{phi-bottom}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
{\it The bottom row in the diagram $(\ast)$
}



\vskip 10pt

Note that we have the following exact sequence in \ref{QSX}


\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$0\to {{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)\stackrel{\lambda}{\longrightarrow} {{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})\stackrel{r(s^P)}{\longrightarrow} {{\mathrm{{\hat{H}om}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(DT, {{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X))\to 0$,}
\vskip 5pt

\noindent and that

\vskip 5pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 20pt
${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})_i={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT, ({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})_i)\oplus  ({{\mathfrak{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^P_{A_X})_{i+1}\otimes_S T$\\
 $= {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT, {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A_{X_{i-1}})\oplus P_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_R DT)\oplus  ({{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A_{X_i})\oplus  P_{A_{X_{i+1}}}\otimes_R DT)\otimes_S T$.
\vskip 5pt

\noindent So we have the following pullback diagram, for some homomorphisms $a_i$,

                             \put(1,6){\vector(1,0){2}}
 \put(9,6){\makebox(0,0)[c]{$_{{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT, \overline{X}_i\otimes_R DT)}$}}
                             \put(17,7){\makebox(0,0)[c]{$_{a_i}$}}
                             \put(16,6){\vector(1,0){2}}
 \put(30,6){\makebox(0,0)[c]{$_{{{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)_i}$}}

\noindent where $r^1_i, r^2_i$ and $\lambda^1_i, \lambda^2_i$ are the components of the homomorphisms $r(s^P)_i$ and $\lambda_i$ respectively, and $b_i={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,t_i)$ with

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$t_i=$ {\footnotesize $(-(q_i\otimes DT)\circ \theta_{l_i},\overline{u}_{X_i}\otimes_R DT): \overline{X}_i\otimes_RDT\to {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A_{X_{i-1}})\oplus P_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_R DT$}}
\vskip 5pt

\noindent is given in \ref{QSX}.


Note that $r^1_i$ is surjective as we indicate in \ref{ker} in the general case, so the upper row is exact. Thus we get the bottom exact sequence in the diagram $(\ast)$.




\vskip 10pt
{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesubsub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}\ (\roman{Exesubsub})}}\hskip 10pt}\label{phi-comm}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
{\it The  diagram $(\ast)$ is commutative
}



\vskip 10pt


At first, it is easy to see that
 the right part of the diagram $(\ast)$ is commutative from the construction of the morphism $\phi$ in 3.4.1.

As to  the left part of the diagram $(\ast)$, we first show that the following equality of  compositions

\hskip 120pt{$\eta^{DT}_{_{\overline{X}_i}}\circ a_i \circ \lambda^1_i=(-q_i,\overline{u}_{X_i},0)\circ \phi_i\circ \lambda^1_i$. \hfill $(\dag_1)$}

Indeed, we have that


\vskip 5pt
\hskip 20pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 50pt
$\eta^{DT}_{_{\overline{X}_i}}\circ a_i \circ \lambda^1_i$\\
$=\eta^{DT}_{_{\overline{X}_i}}\circ b_i $ \hfill (by the commutative diagram in \ref{phi-bottom})\\
$= \eta^{DT}_{_{\overline{X}_i}}\circ {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,t_i)$ \hfill (since $b_i={{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,t_i)$)\\
$={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(1_{\overline{X}_i\otimes_RDT}) \circ  {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(DT,t)$\\
$={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(1_{\overline{X}_i\otimes_RDT}\circ t)$ \hfill (by the naturality  of ${{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}$)\\
$={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(t)$\\
$={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(${\footnotesize $(-(q_i\otimes_R DT)\circ \theta_{l_i},\overline{u}_{X_i}\otimes_R DT)$}$)$ \hfill (since  {\footnotesize $t_i=(-(q_i\otimes DT)\circ \theta_{l_i},\overline{u}_{X_i}\otimes_R DT)$})

\vskip 5pt

\noindent and we also have that


\vskip 5pt
\hskip 20pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 50pt
$(-q_i,\overline{u}_{X_i},0)\circ \phi_i\circ \lambda^1_i$\\
$=(-q_i,\overline{u}_{X_i},0)\circ \xi_i^a$ \hfill (since $\xi_i=(\xi_i^a,\xi_i^b)=\phi\circ \lambda$)\\
$=(-q_i,\overline{u}_{X_i},0)\circ ${\footnotesize ${  \begin{pmatrix} {{\xi^a_{11}}} & {{0}} \\ {{0}} & {{\xi^a_{22}}} \\  {{0}} & {{0}} \end{pmatrix}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$} \hfill (by \ref{xi-a})\\
$=(-q_i\circ \xi^a_{11}, \overline{u}_{X_i}\circ \xi^a_{22}) $.\\
\vskip 5pt

\noindent But $\xi^a_{11}={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(\theta_{l_i})$ and $\xi^a_{22}={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(1_{(P_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_R DT)})$ by the construction in \ref{xi-a}, we obtain that

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$q_i\circ \xi^a_{11}=q_i\circ {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(\theta_{l_i})={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(q_i\otimes_RDT\circ \theta_{l_i})$}
\vskip 5pt

\noindent and that

\vskip 5pt
\centerline{$\overline{u}_{X_i}\circ \xi^a_{22}=\overline{u}_{X_i}\circ {{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(1_{(P_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_R DT)})={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(\overline{u}_{X_i}\otimes_RDT\circ 1_{(P_{A_{X_i}}\otimes_R DT)})={{\mathbf{{\Gamma}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^{DT}(\overline{u}_{X_i}\otimes_RDT)$}
\vskip 5pt

Hence, we see that the equality $(\dag_1)$ holds.

\vskip 5pt
Since that $a_i\circ\lambda^2_i=0$ and that


\centerline{$(-q_i,\overline{u}_{X_i},0)\circ \phi_i\circ \lambda^2_i=(-q_i,\overline{u}_{X_i},0)\circ \xi^b_i=0$,}

\noindent we also get that

\hskip 120pt{$\eta^{DT}_{_{\overline{X}_i}}\circ a_i \circ \lambda^2_i=(-q_i,\overline{u}_{X_i},0)\circ \phi_i\circ \lambda^2_i$. \hfill $(\dag_2)$}

\vskip 5pt
\noindent Now, from the property of  the pullback in \ref{phi-bottom}, we know that the two equalities $(\dag_1)$ and  $(\dag_2)$ together imply that


\centerline{$\eta^{DT}_{_{\overline{X}_i}}\circ a_i=(-q_i,\overline{u}_{X_i},0)\circ \phi_i$.}

\noindent Thus, the left part of the diagram is also commutative.

\vskip 5pt




\vskip 10pt
{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{phi-nat}

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
{\it The isomorphism $\phi: X\oplus {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_X})\to {{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$ is natural on $X$.
}



\vskip 10pt

For any $X,Y\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ and $f\in{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)}(X,Y)$, it is regular to show that the following diagram is commutative, for some natural homomorphisms $f\oplus {{\mathrm{{L}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(P^+_{A_f})$ and ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(f)$.



\vskip 15pt

 \put(39,0){\makebox(0,0)[c]{${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T(X)$.}}

\vskip 10pt



\noindent Thus, the isomorphism $\phi$ is natural on $X$. This means that ${{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T\simeq 1_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}$ naturally.







\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{SQ=1}
{\bf The isomorphism  ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T{{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}\simeq 1_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)}$}



\bskip\


Dually to the proof of \ref{QS=1}, one can show that  ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T{{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}\simeq 1_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)}$ naturally.

Namely, for an object $Y\in{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(S)$, one uses that $({{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0},{{\mathcal{{K}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$ is a complete hereditary cotorsion pair in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$ to obtain exact sequences $0\to K_{Y_i}\to G_{Y_i}\to Y_i\to 0$, for each $i$. Then take an injective $S$-module $I_{G_{Y_i}}$ and a monomorphism $j: G_{Y_i}\to I_{G_{Y_i}}$, one can show that there is a natural isomorphism ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T{{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}(Y)\to Y\oplus {{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DS}(I^-_Y)$, where $I^-_Y=\{I_{G_{Y_{i-1}}}\}$ and ${{\mathrm{{R}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DS}(I^-_Y)$ is a projective object in ${{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(R)$ by Remark (2) in \ref{rFct}. And then one gets that  ${{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T{{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}\simeq 1_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)}$ naturally.







\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{pfth}
{\bf The last proof of main theorem}



\zskip\

Recall that $[1]$ is an automorphism of repetitive categories, where $(X[1])_i=X_{i-1}$ for an object in a repetitive category.

Define ${{\mathbf{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T:=[-1]{{\mathbf{{S}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T: \underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)\to \underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$ and ${{\mathbf{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T:={{\mathbf{{Q}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT}[1]: \underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)\to \underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$. Then we have that ${{\mathbf{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T{{\mathbf{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T\simeq 1_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)}$ naturally and that  ${{\mathbf{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T{{\mathbf{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T\simeq 1_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}$ naturally. So that ${{\mathbf{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$ and ${{\mathbf{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T$ gives a repetitive equivalence between $R$ and $S$.

It is easy to check that ${{\mathbf{{F}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T|_{{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$ and that  ${{\mathbf{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T|_{{{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}\simeq -\otimes_ST$ from the definitions of two functors. Now the proof of the theorem is completed.






\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{pfth}
{\bf The  proof of the proposition in the introduction}



\bskip\

 Assume that the equivalence is given by the functor $F:\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)\to\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$. By assumptions, $F$ restricts to an equivalence ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\to {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Note that ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is resolving and $S\in{{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Let $T=F^{-1}(S)$. Then $T\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. By the triangle equivalence, we have that, for any $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, \\
\centerline{${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^i(T,A)\simeq{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}(T,\Sigma^iA)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)}(S,\Sigma^iF(A))\simeq {{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^i(S,F(A))$,}
where $\Sigma$ is the translator funtor in repetitive categories. In particular, we obtain that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,A)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S(S,F(A))\simeq F(A)$ and that ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^i(T,A)=0$ for all $i>0$.
It follows that  $S\simeq{{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$ and ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^i(T,T)=0$ for all $i>0$.
Note that ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is coresolving and $DR\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, so we also have that $F(DR)\simeq{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,DR)\simeq DT$.   Thus,
we get that  \\
{\footnotesize\centerline{${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^i({_ST},{_ST})\simeq{{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^i(DT,DT)\simeq{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)}(DT,\Sigma^iDT)$\hskip 110pt} \\
\centerline{$\simeq {{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)}(F(DR),\Sigma^iF(DR))\simeq{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)}(DR,\Sigma^iDR)\simeq {{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^i(DR,DR)$.}} It follows that ${{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(_ST)\simeq R$ and that ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^i({_ST},{_ST})=0$ for all $i>0$. Thus, $T$ is a Wakamatsu-tilting module.

By assumption, $F|_{{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}\simeq{{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$ gives the equivalence ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\to {{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. It follows that $F^{-1}|_{{{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}\simeq -\otimes_ST$ by the unique of the adjoint. Note that ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$ and $-\otimes_ST$ are exact functors respectively in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and ${{{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}$, since $F$ is a triangle functor. As ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is coresolving, for any $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, the exact sequence $0\to A\to I\to A'\to 0$ with $I\in{{\mathrm{{inj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ is a sequence in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Applying the exact functor ${{\mathrm{{Hom}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R(T,-)$, we obtain that ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(T,A)=0$. It follows that $T\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}\bigcap{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^1_R(-,{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0})$, i.e, $T$ is Ext-projective in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Dually, we have also that ${{\mathrm{{Tor}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^S_1(X,T)=0$ for any $X\in{{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. In particular, for any $A\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$, suppose that $A=X\otimes_ST$ for some $X\in{{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ and take an exact sequence $0\to X'\to P\to X\to 0$ with $P\in{{\mathrm{{proj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$, then the sequence is in ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ since ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$ is resolving, and hence there is an induced exact sequence $0\to  X'\otimes_ST\to P\otimes_ST\to X\otimes_ST\to 0$, since $-\otimes_ST$ is exact in ${{\mathcal{{G}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. The last sequence gives an exact sequence $0\to A''\to T_A\to A\to 0$ with $T_A= P\otimes_ST\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$ and $A''=X'\to P\in{{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. It follows that $T$ is an Ext-projective generator in ${{\mathcal{{A}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}$. Now applying Corollary \ref{c-gwt}, we conclude that $T$ is a good Wakamatsu-tilting module.













\vskip 30pt

\section{\large Examples}







{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{t-ct}
{\bf Tilting modules and cotilting modules }


\vskip 10pt
Let $R$ ba an artin algebra. Recall that an $R$-module $T$ is tilting provided the following three conditions are satisfied:

\vskip 5pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
(1) The projective dimension of $T$ is finite;

(2) ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^i(T,T)=0$ for all $i>0$;

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
(3) There is an exact sequence $0\to R\to T_0\to\cdots\to T_n\to 0$ for some integer $n$, where each $T_i\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$.

\vskip 5pt
\noindent
Dually, an $R$-module $T$ is cotilting provided the following three conditions are satisfied:

\vskip 5pt
\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
(1) The injective dimension of $T$ is finite;

(2) ${{\mathrm{{Ext}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^i(T,T)=0$ for all $i>0$;

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
(3) There is an exact sequence $0\to T_n\to\cdots\to T_0\to DR\to 0$ for some integer $n$, where each $T_i\in{{\mathrm{{add}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_RT$.

\vskip 5pt
It is known that an $R$-module $T$ is a tilting module if and only if $DT$ is a cotilting left $R$-module if and only if $DT$ is a cotilting $S$-module. Note also that both tilting modules and cotilting modules are Wakamatsu-tilting modules.

We need the following well-known results on tilting modules and cotilting modules.

\vskip 10pt
\noindent\hangafter 1\hangindent 38pt
{\bf Proposition} {\it 
$(1)$ If $T$ is a tilting module, then the cortorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ is complete.

\hangafter 1\hangindent 40pt
$(2)$ If $T$ is a cotilting module, then the cortorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,-))$ is complete.
}

\vskip 5pt
\noindent
\Pf. (2)  follows from \cite[Section 5]{AR}, and (1) is just the dual of (2).

\hfill $\Box$


\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{tm}
{\it Tilting modules are  good Wakamatsu-tilting}


\vskip 10pt

Assume $T_R$ is a tilting module of finite projective dimension. Let $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$. Then $_ST_R$ is a good Wakamatsu-tilting module. Hence there is an equivalence between repetitive categories $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ and $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$.

Indeed, if $_ST_R$ is a tilting module of finite projective dimension, then  $T$ is Wakamatsu-tilting and $_RDT_S$ is a cotilting module of finite injective dimension. By Proposition \ref{cotp}, we obtain that  bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between the compete hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and the compete hereditary cotorsion pair  $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT},{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT},-))$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$. It follows from the definition that $_ST_R$ is a good Wakamatsu-tilting bimodule.



\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{tm}
{\it Cotilting modules are  good Wakamatsu-tilting}


\vskip 10pt

Assume now $T_R$ is a cotilting module of finite injective dimension with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$. Then $_ST_R$ is also a good Wakamatsu-tilting module. Hence there is an equivalence between repetitive categories $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(R)$ and $\underline{{{\mathcal{{RC}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}(S)$.


Indeed, dually to \ref{tm}, if $_ST_R$ is a cotilting module of finite injective dimension, then $_RDT_S$ is a tilting module of finite projective dimension. By Proposition \ref{cotp} again, we obtain that  bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between the compete hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{T},{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{T},-))$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and the compete hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$.  It follows from the definition that $_ST_R$ is also a good Wakamatsu-tilting bimodule.





\zskip\

{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exe}\textbf{            {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{fpt}
{\bf Wakamatsu-tilting modules of finite  type}


\vskip 10pt


{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{wfpt}




We say  that a  Wakamatsu-tilting $R$-module $T$ is of finite  type provided that either the subcategory ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ or  the subcategory ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,-)$ is of finite representation type.
In particular, if $R$ is an algebra of finite representation type, then each subcategory of ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ is of finite representation type, and hence every Wakamatsu-tilting module in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ is of finite  type.

We note that, if $T$ is a  Wakamatsu-tilting $R$-module of finite  type with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$, then $DT$ is a Wakamatsu-tilting $S$-module of finite type. This is just followed from the equivalences in Proposition \ref{cotp}.


\vskip 10pt
\noindent
{\bf Proposition}\ \ 
{\it A  Wakamatsu-tilting module of finite  type is always a good  Wakamatsu-tilting module. In particular,  every Wakamatsu-tilting module over an  algebra of finite representation type is good.
}

\vskip 5pt
\noindent
\Pf. Let $T$ be a  Wakamatsu-tilting $R$-module of finite  type with $S={{\mathrm{{End}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}(T_R)$. Assume first that  the subcategory ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,-)$ is of finite representation type. Then the hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{T},{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{T},-))$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ is complete. Moreover, by the equivalence in Proposition \ref{cotp} (3), the subcategory ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ is also  of finite representation type. Thus, the hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$ is also complete. It follows that  bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between the compete hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{T},{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{T},-))$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and the compete hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_{DT}{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$.  Similarly, in case that ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ is of finite representation type, we have that  bimodules $_ST_R$ and $_RDT_S$ represent a cotorsion pair counter equivalence between the compete hereditary cotorsion pair $({{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}}),{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ and the compete hereditary cotorsion pair  $({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT},{{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_S^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_{DT},-))$ in ${{\mathrm{{mod}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}S$. Altogether, we see that $T$ is a good Wakamatsu-tilting module in either case.

\hfill $\Box$



\vskip 10pt


{\vskip 10pt\noindent\refstepcounter{Exesub}\textbf{            {\noindent {\noindent \thesection.\arabic{Exe}}.\arabic{Exesub}}}\hskip 10pt}\label{wfpt}




Two trivial examples of Wakamatsu-tilting modules of finite  type over an algebra $R$ is the module $R$ and the module $DR$. In the first case, the subcategory ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1(-,{_T{{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}})={{\mathrm{{proj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ is of finite representation type, while the subcategory ${{\mathrm{{KerExt}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_R^1({{\mathcal{{X}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}_T,-)={{\mathrm{{inj}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}R$ is of finite representation type in the second case.

The following is an example of Wakamatsu-tilting modules of finite  type over an algebra of infinite representation type.

\noindent{\bf Example} Let $R$ be the bounded quiver algebra given by the following quiver over a field with the relation given by ${{\mathrm{{rad}}}}\setcounter{equation}{0}^2R=0$.
